posts.post_content:
If you discard 2 lands, then your opponent one, then you one more, it would deal 11 damage. Each discarded land adds 2 counters.  
  
Interesting, but I don't know how practical it would be. Unless you can be sure that an opponent can't (or won't) pitch more lands than you, it's a very poor choice.
posts.html:

Posted By: Andon_A (4/6/2010 11:49:10 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Technically your opponent could just use the ability once you're finished discarding. It's too risky. You need to make sure that your opponent's either have no land cards to discard, or they are not willing to discard cards.
  
   
I've never used this card before, but it looks like you should use it with at least 3 land cards in your hand, and you discard two right away. Keep the last one for safety. If your opponent discards, you use that last land. It is unlikely your opponeny will discard more than one. And with just four charge counters on it, you can deal *7 damage*!!
posts.html:

Posted By: Mata-nui3 (2/5/2011 1:07:47 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
I thought this was a pretty fun spike card until I reread the activated ability and realized the target could change and other players could activate it and change the target. I'm picturing a very large burn spell with a built in redirect clause that could cause some real shenanigans.   
  
If you had a [Runed Halo](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Runed Halo) out and nothing your spell could bomb on your side, it would be pretty awesome. However, the fact that you don't pitch your lands on resolution but while it's still on the stack means that you could be at severe card disadvantage if one were to counter this.  
  
All in all this is a very red spell.  
  
3.5/ 5
posts.html:
I thought this was a pretty fun spike card until I reread the activated ability and realized the target could change and other players could activate it and change the target. I'm picturing a very large burn spell with a built in redirect clause that could cause some real shenanigans.

If you had a Runed Halo out and nothing your spell could bomb on your side, it would be pretty awesome. However, the fact that you don't pitch your lands on resolution but while it's still on the stack means that you could be at severe card disadvantage if one were to counter this.

All in all this is a very red spell.

3.5/ 5
